title: Erdős Problem #595: Infinite Graphs and Countable Triangle-Free Decomposition
description: Is there an infinite graph G which contains no K₄ and is not the union of countably many triangle-free graphs? A fundamental question by Erdős and Hajnal about the chromatic structure of infinite graphs.

overview.historicalContext: This problem originated from Erdős and Hajnal around 1967, exploring the chromatic properties of infinite graphs. It asks whether a 'local' constraint (K₄-free) can coexist with 'global' resistance to decomposition. The problem connects to Folkman numbers and general Ramsey-type decomposition questions.
overview.problemStatement: Is there an infinite graph G which contains no K₄ and is not the union of countably many triangle-free graphs?
overview.proofStrategy: The problem remains OPEN. The finite case is completely solved: Folkman (1970) and Nešetřil-Rödl (1975) proved that for every n ≥ 1, there exists a K₄-free graph that cannot be covered by n triangle-free graphs. The jump to countably infinite covers introduces fundamentally new difficulties.
keyInsights: Finite resistance does not automatically imply countable resistance
C₄-free graphs are countably coverable by trees (Erdős-Hajnal)
The problem is the (K₄, K₃) special case of the general (G₁, G₂) question (Problem 596)
Related to Folkman numbers (Problem 582) which concern finite graphs with Ramsey properties

sections.title: The Finite Case: Folkman-Nešetřil-Rödl
sections.summary: For every finite n ≥ 1, there exists a K₄-free graph that cannot be expressed as the union of n triangle-free graphs. This was proved independently by Folkman (1970) and Nešetřil-Rödl (1975) using different methods.

sections.title: The Countable Gap
sections.summary: The key difficulty in extending to the countable case: a family of graphs {G_n} where G_n resists n-covers might still collectively admit a countable covering when suitably combined. This finite-to-countable gap is the essence of the problem.

sections.title: Connection to Problem 596
sections.summary: Problem 596 asks the general question: for which pairs (G₁, G₂) do we have finite resistance but countable covering? Problem 595 is the specific case G₁ = K₄, G₂ = K₃ (triangle). The (C₄, C₆) pair is known to have this property.

sections.title: Related Results
sections.summary: Erdős and Hajnal proved that every C₄-free graph is a countable union of trees. Since trees are triangle-free, C₄-free graphs ARE countably coverable. This contrasts with the K₄-free case which remains open.

conclusion.summary: Problem 595 remains one of the significant open problems in infinite graph theory. The $250 prize reflects its difficulty. The finite analogues are well-understood, but the countable case requires fundamentally new ideas.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would demonstrate a deep structural difference between finite and countable decomposability. A negative answer would establish a powerful compactness-type result for graph coverings.
openQuestions: Does such an infinite K₄-free graph exist?
Can probabilistic or algebraic methods construct an explicit example?
What set-theoretic methods might be applicable?
